issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery should take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) while the reference solution implements acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) — only three parameters (no supplier name). This mismatch in method parameters will confuse students about the expected signature and lead to compilation/test failures if they follow the UML/text literally.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement and UML consistent with the actual implementation. Either (A) update the UML/text to show acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (dropping the supplier-name parameter), or (B) change the reference/template implementation to include the supplier name parameter (e.g., acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity)). Ensure tests and examples are updated accordingly.

issues.description: The problem text instructs students to create a final Stock stock and initialize it in the SealSaloon constructor, but also requires that the stock attribute be static (shared across instances). In Java a static final field cannot be assigned in an instance constructor (it must be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer). This is an internal contradiction in the specification that can lead students to attempt an invalid implementation and compilation errors.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the intended initialization approach for the shared stock. Preferable fixes: (A) Update the problem statement to instruct students to declare the stock as static final and initialize it at declaration (or in a static initializer) rather than in the instance constructor, or (B) if the intent is to initialize it in the constructor, remove the requirement that the field be static. Align the textual instructions, UML, and any examples to match the chosen approach.

issues.description: The problem statement specifies SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — see UML and textual description — but both the provided template Main (commented usage) and the solution implement/use a three-parameter variant (ingredient name, price, quantity). Concretely, the problem text expects acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int) while the solution implements acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity). This discrepancy (missing supplier parameter / different parameter list) creates a mismatch between the requirement and the code students will see and run, causing confusion about the expected method signature and potentially breaking tests or example calls.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the signature consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the solution and template usage to include the supplier parameter so the method matches the problem statement: public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (and update all calls), or (B) update the problem statement (and UML) to require the three-parameter form (ingredientName, price, quantity) to match the template and solution. Choose one consistent signature and apply it to the UML, textual description, template example calls, and the solution implementation.
